intro: Brassica oleracea var. ulmensis, commonly known as the wild cabbage, is a perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its robust, hairy stems and large, lobed leaves that can grow up to 30 cm in length. The plant produces yellow flowers in clusters, which are followed by round, green, edible pods containing small, round seeds. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, known for its characteristic cruciform flowers and mustard oils. This variety is often used in botanical studies due to its genetic diversity and adaptability to various climates.
